### Accolades[edit]


Main article: List of accolades received by *Star Wars: The Force Awakens*

Several awards held their nominations before the December release of *The Force Awakens*, making the film ineligible for the 73rd Golden Globe Awards and some other awards ceremonies.[352] However, the film was added to the 21st Critics' Choice Awards' slate of best picture nominees after a special vote by the board of directors,[353] and the announcement of the 2015 American Film Institute Awards was delayed until after the release of *The Force Awakens*,[352] where it was named one of the top-ten films of 2015.[354]


At the 88th Academy Awards, *The Force Awakens* received nominations for Best Film Editing, Best Original Score, Best Sound Editing, Best Sound Mixing, and Best Visual Effects.[355] The film's other nominations include four British Academy Film Awards (winning one) and a Critics' Choice Movie Award.[356][357]



### Fan backlash[edit]




</fragment>
<fragment>
Advance ticket sales for the film began on October 19, 2015,[254] and were in strong demand, resulting in online movie ticket sites crashing.[255][256] Vue Cinemas, the United Kingdom's third-largest theater chain, sold 45,000 tickets in 24 hours, 10,000 of which were sold in 90 minutes, a record for the theater.[257] In the United States, the film pre-sold a record-breaking $6.5 million worth of IMAX ticket sales on a single day. IMAX has never previously registered more than $1 million in pre-sales on a single day.[258] In total, it sold over $50 million in pre-sales, breaking the record.[259][260] This number was raised to $100 million including $50–60 million in advance ticket sales by December 14.[260][261] However, not all tickets that were pre-sold were for the film's opening weekend, with Fandango President Paul Yanover saying "people have set aside tickets for screenings in January, weeks after the big opening [...] We have people buying *Star Wars* [*The Force Awakens*] into 2016.

<fragment>

The film was announced after The Walt Disney Company's acquisition of Lucasfilm in October 2012. The film is the first *Star Wars* film to not extensively involve franchise creator George Lucas, who only served as a creative consultant in the early stages of production. *The Force Awakens* was produced by Abrams, his longtime collaborator Bryan Burk, and Lucasfilm president Kathleen Kennedy. Abrams and Lawrence Kasdan, co-writer of the original trilogy films *The Empire Strikes Back* (1980) and *Return of the Jedi*, rewrote an initial script by Michael Arndt. John Williams, composer for the previous episodic films, returned to compose the score. Principal photography began in April 2014 and concluded the following November. Filming took place on sets at Pinewood Studios in England, and on location mainly in Abu Dhabi, Iceland, and Ireland. On a budget of $447 million, it is the most expensive film ever made.

## Release[edit]


### Theatrical[edit]


![](image)The premiere tent, with the film's poster above
*Star Wars: The Force Awakens* premiered on December 14, 2015, at the TCL Chinese Theatre, El Capitan Theatre, and Dolby Theatre in Hollywood, Los Angeles.[244] A white tent stretched along Hollywood Boulevard from Orange Drive to Highland Avenue, covering the "massive" premiere event that hosted more than five thousand guests.[245] The film was originally scheduled for a mid-2015 release, but in November 2013, it was pushed back to December 18, 2015.[246] It was also released in 3D, RealD 3D and IMAX 3D formats.[247]

<fragment>
*Star Wars: The Force Awakens* grossed $936.7 million in the United States and Canada and $1.132 billion in other countries for a worldwide total of $2.068 billion,[3] making it the highest-grossing film of 2015[280] and the third highest-grossing film of all time.[281] Box Office Mojo estimates that the film sold close to 110 million tickets in the United States and Canada.[282] *The Force Awakens* earned 8.6% of the total 2015 releases in the United States and Canada, second only to the 8.8% of the box office earned by *Titanic* in 1997.[283] It was the 24th film in cinematic history to gross $1 billion worldwide, standing as the fastest film to surpass the mark at the time, doing so in 12 days.[284] It was also the third film in history to surpass $2 billion worldwide, doing so on its 53rd day of release.[285] *Deadline Hollywood* calculated the film's net profit as $780.1 million, accounting for production budgets, marketing, talent participations, 
</fragment>
<fragment>
281. **^** "Worldwide Grosses". *Box Office Mojo*. Archived from the original on January 6, 2017. Retrieved October 21, 2021.
282. **^** "Domestic Grosses Adjusted for Ticket Price Inflation". Box Office Mojo. Archived from the original on December 20, 2016. Retrieved July 12, 2016.
283. **^** Mendelson, Scott (March 11, 2016). "Hollywood Is Doomed Because 'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' Made Too Much Money?". *Forbes*. Archived from the original on March 14, 2016. Retrieved March 11, 2016.

285. **^** D'Alessandro, Anthony (February 5, 2016). "'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' Reaches Unprecedented Height At Domestic B.O. With $900M, $2B Worldwide". *Deadline Hollywood*. Archived from the original on February 6, 2016. Retrieved February 7, 2016.

</fragment>
<fragment>
After five days, the film had a total worldwide opening record of $529 million from 74 territories, which was the biggest worldwide opening at that time, making it only the second time in cinematic history—after *Jurassic World*—that a film had opened to more than $500 million globally.[319][322] This included an IMAX opening record of $48 million.[322] Revenues from IMAX dipped slightly, generating $19 million in its second weekend, for a record total of over $70 million in 11 days.[323] IMAX generated $17.9 million from 276 IMAX theaters.[301] The film had a steeper decline in its second weekend, falling 51% to $136.9 million.[324] The film had an unsuccessful opening in India where it opened third against two local blockbusters with a mere $1.51 million.[325] As of February 2016, the highest-grossing markets outside of the United States and Canada were the United Kingdom ($180.7 million), China ($124.5 million), Germany ($109.7 million), Japan ($92.6 million), 
</fragment>
<fragment>
320. **^** "Overseas Total All Time Openings". Box Office Mojo. Archived from the original on June 23, 2011. Retrieved January 4, 2016.

322. ^ ***a*** ***b*** Brevet, Brad (December 20, 2015). "'Star Wars: The Force Awakens' Crushes Records, Topping Largest Box Office Weekend of All Time". Box Office Mojo. Archived from the original on December 20, 2015. Retrieved December 21, 2015.
323. **^** D'Alessandro, Anthony; Busch, Anita (December 27, 2015). "'Daddy', 'Joy' & 'Hateful Eight' Reap Fortune As 'Star Wars' Hits $540M+ … Can 'Force Awakens' Hit $1 Billion in U.S.?". *Deadline Hollywood*. Archived from the original on December 27, 2015. Retrieved December 28, 2015.

</fragment>
<fragment>

On January 2, after just 16 days of release, it became the second film (following *Avatar*) to gross over $700 million in the United States and Canada,[307] and on January 6 became the highest-grossing film of all time domestically, doing so in 20 days.[308] On January 9, it became the first film in cinematic history to cross $800 million domestically unadjusted for inflation.[309] On February 5, *The Force Awakens* became the first film to earn over $900 million, unadjusted for inflation, in the United States and Canada.[310][311] The film fell outside of the top ten for the first time in its eleventh weekend during the weekend February 26–28, 2016,[312][313] and did not achieve $1 million in ticket sales for the first time in its fourteenth weekend.[314]



#### Other territories[edit]


</fragment>
<fragment>
and France ($88.2 million).[326] On January 17, 2016, it passed the $1 billion mark overseas becoming the first film of Disney, the third film of 2015 and the fifth film overall to achieve this feat.[327] It topped the international box office chart for five consecutive weekends, becoming the first film since *Avengers: Age of Ultron* (2015) to have five straight wins, before being dethroned by *The Revenant* in its sixth weekend.[328] In Japan, it topped the box office for six straight weekends.[328]

#### Commercial analysis[edit]


Analysts said that the box office receipts of the film, when compared to predecessors, must be adjusted for inflation, and that the first *Star Wars* film made more when this adjustment is made.[286] It has further been observed that each of the first three films in the series was more profitable in calculating revenue against production costs.[286]

It made a record-breaking $57 million from Thursday night previews,[b] of which IMAX screenings generated a record-breaking $5.7 million from 391 screens.[295] On its opening day, the film grossed $119.1 million, marking the biggest single- and opening-day record[296] and the first time a film has earned more than $100 million in a single day.[297] Without Thursday-night grosses, the film earned the second-largest opening-day gross[298] and a record of $247.9 million for its opening weekend.[273] The debut was 19% bigger than the previous record holders *The Avengers* (2012) ($207 million) and *Jurassic World* (2015) ($208 million).[299] The opening weekend figure included an IMAX opening-weekend record of $30.1 million (12.65%) from 391 IMAX theaters,[300][301] which nearly amounts to the $252.5 million total earned by *Return of the Jedi*—the second-lowest-grossing film in the series—in its original run.[302] 2D screenings accounted for 53% of the total opening gross while 3D accounted for 47%.

The score was recorded in 12 sessions within a five-month period between June and mid-November. The 90-piece orchestra recorded 175 minutes of music; however, Abrams reedited the film, which discarded, modified, or rerecorded the score's part for nearly an hour. Williams' theme for Snoke was recorded by a 24-voice men's chorus.[200] Gustavo Dudamel conducted the opening and end title music for the film at Williams' behest.[201] Recording of the score was completed on November 14, 2015.[202] The film's soundtrack was released by Walt Disney Records on December 18, 2015.[203] Williams' score is more than two hours long.[195]

Nancy Tartaglione of *Deadline Hollywood* argued that, if accounting for its 40/60 domestic to international split, *The Force Awakens* did well overseas.[289] While the film had special effects, analysts felt that it lacked the novelty factor; they also stated that its gross was stilted due to markets making way for new films sooner than was previously done.[288] Dergarabedian stated, "No matter what, [*The Force Awakens*] is an absolute, all-out blockbuster without peer in terms of the sheer speed at which it has crossed all of these major box-office milestones."[287] Moreover, Mike Fleming Jr. of *Deadline Hollywood* argued that the movie was the "most valuable movie" of the year, with "the net profit to Disney was an astounding $780.11M, and the Cash on Cash Return was twice that of any other film [released in 2016], at 2.00".[291]

*The Force Awakens* was followed by *The Last Jedi* in 2017.[363] The film's plot follows the Resistance escaping from the First Order.[364] Like the previous film, *The Last Jedi* was a financial success and fared well with critics.[365]


A sequel to *The Last Jedi* was released in 2019, titled *The Rise of Skywalker*.[366] As the conclusion to the Skywalker narrative,[367] it focuses on the Resistance assault on the Final Order, a reorganized First Order.[364] Critics' reactions to *The Rise of Skywalker* were mixed.[368][369]

In the United States and Canada, it had the widest release of December across 4,134 theaters,[248] of which 3,300 were 3D locations, a record 392 IMAX screens (13 of which were 70mm), 451 premium large format screens, 146 D-Box locations,[249][250] as well as releasing in the Dolby Vision format (high-dynamic range, Rec. 2020 color) in Dolby Cinema.[251] Worldwide, it was released across 940 IMAX theaters, a new record.[250] On December 18, 2015, the film began playing on every IMAX screen in the United States and Canada for four straight weeks up to January 14, 2016. This made it the first film since Warner Bros.' *The Hobbit* trilogy to receive such a release.[252] The film finally shed some of its IMAX screens with the release of *The Revenant* (2015) and *The Finest Hours* (2016) in mid-January 2016.[253]

Internationally, the film was released in over 30,000 screens.[315] It opened on December 16, 2015, in 12 international markets and earned $14.1 million on its opening day, debuting at first place in all of them.[316] It expanded in an additional 42 countries on December 17, generating $58.6 million for a two-day international total of $72.7 million, reaching first place in all 44 markets.[317] It grossed a total of $129.5 million in three days after adding $56.8 million on its third day,[317] and set a new midnight record in the United Kingdom with $3.6 million.[318] It broke opening-day records in the United Kingdom ($14.4 million), Germany ($7.1 million), Australia ($6.8 million),[295] Sweden ($1.7 million), Norway ($1.1 million),[316] and in 12 other countries.[318] Other markets which generated large opening days were Spain ($3.5 million) and Japan ($3 million).[317] After the five days, *The Force Awakens* had a total international opening gross of $281 million from 30,000 screens,

***Star Wars: The Force Awakens*** (also known as ***Star Wars: Episode VII – The Force Awakens***) is a 2015 American epic space opera film co-produced, co-written, and directed by J. J. Abrams. The sequel to *Return of the Jedi* (1983), it is the seventh film in the "Skywalker Saga". Set thirty years after *Return of the Jedi*, *The Force Awakens* follows Rey, Finn, Poe Dameron, and Han Solo's search for Luke Skywalker and their fight in the Resistance, led by General Leia Organa and veterans of the Rebel Alliance, against Kylo Ren and the First Order, a successor to the Galactic Empire. The ensemble cast includes Harrison Ford, Mark Hamill, Carrie Fisher, Adam Driver, Daisy Ridley, John Boyega, Oscar Isaac, Lupita Nyong'o, Andy Serkis, Domhnall Gleeson, Anthony Daniels, Peter Mayhew, and Max von Sydow.

### Music[edit]


Main article: *Star Wars: The Force Awakens* (soundtrack)


</fragment>
<fragment>

*The Force Awakens* premiered in Hollywood, Los Angeles, on December 14, 2015, and was released in the United States on December 18. It was positively received by critics, who found it an action-packed film with the mix of new and familiar actors capturing the nostalgia of the original trilogy and giving the franchise new energy.[4] The film grossed $2.07 billion worldwide, breaking various box office records and becoming the highest-grossing film in the United States and Canada, the highest-grossing film of 2015, and the third-highest-grossing film at the time of its release. It was nominated for five awards at the 88th Academy Awards, and received numerous other accolades. The film was followed by *The Last Jedi* (2017) and *The Rise of Skywalker* (2019), rounding out the *Star Wars* sequel trilogy.

In July 2013, John Williams was confirmed to return to compose the sequel trilogy, beginning with *The Force Awakens*.[193] He began working on the film in December 2014, and by June 2015 had been through most of the film reels, working on a daily basis.[194][195] In May 2015, Williams said he would return to themes from the previous films, such as those for Luke, Leia, and Han, in ways that "there are a few that I think are important and will seem very much a part of the fabric of the piece in a positive and constructive way." He said that working with Abrams was similar to the process he went through with Lucas in the earlier films.[196]


Recording sessions for *The Force Awakens* began in June 2015 at the Sony Pictures Studios' Barbra Streisand Scoring Stage in Culver City, with William Ross conducting most of the music.[197] The first day of recording was June 1, 2015.[198] Williams attended the sessions and conducted the remainder of the recordings in Los Angeles.[199]

Lin-Manuel Miranda and Abrams contributed music to the film's cantina scene. Abrams met Miranda at a performance of his Broadway musical *Hamilton*, where Miranda jokingly offered to compose cantina music, should it be needed. Unknown to Miranda, Williams had previously told Abrams that he did not want to compose the music for that scene, wanting to focus on the orchestral score. Abrams then contacted Miranda, and the two collaborated on the music for the scene over a period of two months.[204]

### Accolades[edit]


Main article: List of accolades received by *Star Wars: The Force Awakens*

Several awards held their nominations before the December release of *The Force Awakens*, making the film ineligible for the 73rd Golden Globe Awards and some other awards ceremonies.[352] However, the film was added to the 21st Critics' Choice Awards' slate of best picture nominees after a special vote by the board of directors,[353] and the announcement of the 2015 American Film Institute Awards was delayed until after the release of *The Force Awakens*,[352] where it was named one of the top-ten films of 2015.[354]


At the 88th Academy Awards, *The Force Awakens* received nominations for Best Film Editing, Best Original Score, Best Sound Editing, Best Sound Mixing, and Best Visual Effects.[355] The film's other nominations include four British Academy Film Awards (winning one) and a Critics' Choice Movie Award.[356][357]



### Fan backlash[edit]




</fragment>
<fragment>
Advance ticket sales for the film began on October 19, 2015,[254] and were in strong demand, resulting in online movie ticket sites crashing.[255][256] Vue Cinemas, the United Kingdom's third-largest theater chain, sold 45,000 tickets in 24 hours, 10,000 of which were sold in 90 minutes, a record for the theater.[257] In the United States, the film pre-sold a record-breaking $6.5 million worth of IMAX ticket sales on a single day. IMAX has never previously registered more than $1 million in pre-sales on a single day.[258] In total, it sold over $50 million in pre-sales, breaking the record.[259][260] This number was raised to $100 million including $50–60 million in advance ticket sales by December 14.[260][261] However, not all tickets that were pre-sold were for the film's opening weekend, with Fandango President Paul Yanover saying "people have set aside tickets for screenings in January, weeks after the big opening [...] We have people buying *Star Wars* [*The Force Awakens*] into 2016.

</fragment>
<fragment>

The film was announced after The Walt Disney Company's acquisition of Lucasfilm in October 2012. The film is the first *Star Wars* film to not extensively involve franchise creator George Lucas, who only served as a creative consultant in the early stages of production. *The Force Awakens* was produced by Abrams, his longtime collaborator Bryan Burk, and Lucasfilm president Kathleen Kennedy. Abrams and Lawrence Kasdan, co-writer of the original trilogy films *The Empire Strikes Back* (1980) and *Return of the Jedi*, rewrote an initial script by Michael Arndt. John Williams, composer for the previous episodic films, returned to compose the score. Principal photography began in April 2014 and concluded the following November. Filming took place on sets at Pinewood Studios in England, and on location mainly in Abu Dhabi, Iceland, and Ireland. On a budget of $447 million, it is the most expensive film ever made.

## Release[edit]


### Theatrical[edit]


![](image)The premiere tent, with the film's poster above
*Star Wars: The Force Awakens* premiered on December 14, 2015, at the TCL Chinese Theatre, El Capitan Theatre, and Dolby Theatre in Hollywood, Los Angeles.[244] A white tent stretched along Hollywood Boulevard from Orange Drive to Highland Avenue, covering the "massive" premiere event that hosted more than five thousand guests.[245] The film was originally scheduled for a mid-2015 release, but in November 2013, it was pushed back to December 18, 2015.[246] It was also released in 3D, RealD 3D and IMAX 3D formats.[247]

msg.content:
Here is a summary of the box office performance and records of the films "Avatar (2009)", "Avengers: Endgame", "Avatar: The Way of Water", "Titanic (1997)", and "Star Wars: The Force Awakens":

### Avatar (2009)
- **Worldwide Gross**: $2.922 billion
- **Highest-Grossing Film**: Became the highest-grossing film of all time in 2010, surpassing "Titanic".
- **Re-Releases**: Subsequent re-releases, including in China in 2021, helped it regain the top spot from "Avengers: Endgame".
- **Box Office Records**: Fastest film to gross $1 billion, highest-grossing film in multiple countries, and first film to gross over $2 billion worldwide.

### Avengers: Endgame
- **Worldwide Gross**: $2.799 billion
- **Highest-Grossing Film**: Surpassed "Avatar" in 2019 to become the highest-grossing film of all time until "Avatar" reclaimed the title in 2021.
- **Opening Records**: Largest worldwide opening of $1.2 billion, fastest film to gross $1 billion (5 days) and $2 billion (11 days).
- **Domestic Records**: Fastest film to gross $600 million domestically, highest-grossing film in the US and Canada.

### Avatar: The Way of Water
- **Worldwide Gross**: $2.320 billion
- **Highest-Grossing Film**: Third-highest-grossing film of all time.
- **Pandemic Era**: Highest-grossing film of the pandemic era.
- **Box Office Records**: Fastest film to gross $1 billion in the pandemic era (14 days), and the second-fastest to gross $2 billion (40 days).

### Titanic (1997)
- **Worldwide Gross**: $2.257 billion
- **Highest-Grossing Film**: Held the title of highest-grossing film of all time for 12 years until "Avatar" surpassed it in 2010.
- **Box Office Records**: First film to gross over $1 billion worldwide, highest-grossing film in multiple countries, and remained in theaters for almost 10 months.
- **Re-Releases**: Multiple re-releases, including a 3D version in 2012, contributed to its total gross.

### Star Wars: The Force Awakens
- **Worldwide Gross**: $2.068 billion
- **Highest-Grossing Film**: Third-highest-grossing film of all time at the time of its release.
- **Box Office Records**: Fastest film to gross $1 billion worldwide (12 days), highest-grossing film in the US and Canada, and first film to earn over $900 million domestically.
- **Opening Records**: Largest opening weekend in North America ($247.9 million), and highest single-day gross ($119.1 million).

These films have set numerous box office records and have been re-released multiple times, contributing to their high lifetime grosses.
